MindFlayer: Efficient Asynchronous Parallel SGD
in the Presence of Heterogeneous and
Random Worker Compute Times

Artavazd Maranjyan
KAUST
arto.maranjyan@gmail.com
&Omar Shaikh Omar
KAUST
omar.shaikhomar@kaust.edu.sa
Peter Richtárik
KAUST
peter.richtarik@kaust.edu.sa
Abstract

We study the problem of minimizing the expectation of smooth nonconvex functions with the help of several parallel workers whose role is to compute stochastic gradients. In particular, we focus on the challenging situation where the workers’ compute times are arbitrarily heterogeneous and random. In the simpler regime characterized by arbitrarily heterogeneous but deterministic compute times, Tyurin and Richtárik, (2024) recently proposed the first optimal asynchronous SGD method, called Rennala SGD, in terms of a novel complexity notion called time complexity. The starting point of our work is the observation that Rennala SGD can have arbitrarily bad performance in the presence of random compute times – a setting it was not designed to handle. To advance our understanding of stochastic optimization in this challenging regime, we propose a new asynchronous SGD method, for which we coin the name MindFlayer SGD. Our theory and empirical results demonstrate the superiority of MindFlayer SGD over existing baselines, including Rennala SGD, in cases when the noise is heavy tailed.

1 Introduction

We address the nonconvex optimization problem:

minx∈ℝd⁡{f⁢(x):=𝔼ξ∼𝒟⁢[f⁢(x;ξ)]},subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑assign𝑓𝑥subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉𝒟delimited-[]𝑓𝑥𝜉\displaystyle\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\Big{\{}f(x):={\mathbb{E}}_{\xi\sim% \mathcal{D}}\left[f(x;\xi)\right]\Big{\}},roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_f ( italic_x ) := blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_ξ ) ] } , (1)

where f:ℝd×𝕊→ℝ,:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑𝕊ℝf\,:\,\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{S}\rightarrow\mathbb{R},italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × blackboard_S → blackboard_R , and ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is a random variable with some distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D on 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S}blackboard_S. In the context of machine learning, 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S}blackboard_S could represent the space of all possible data, 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D denotes the distribution of the training dataset, and f⁢(⋅;ξ)𝑓⋅𝜉f(\cdot;\xi)italic_f ( ⋅ ; italic_ξ ) denotes the loss of a data sample ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ.

The function f𝑓fitalic_f is assumed to be differentiable, and its gradient is L𝐿Litalic_L–Lipschitz continuous (see Assumptions 4.1–4.2). We assume that we have n𝑛nitalic_n workers available to work in parallel, each able to compute independent, unbiased stochastic gradients of f𝑓fitalic_f, whose variance is bounded by σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see Assumption 4.3). In this paper, we are interested in investigating the time complexity of methods working in this natural setup.

1.1 Minibatch SGD

With access to n𝑛nitalic_n clients capable of computing stochastic gradients in parallel, perhaps the most naive and classical approach is running Minibatch SGD (Cotter et al., , 2011; Goyal et al., , 2017; Gower et al., , 2019). This method awaits the completion of all workers’ computations of a single stochastic gradient before executing a gradient-type step:

  1. 1.

    receive a single stochastic gradient ∇f⁢(xk;ξik)∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{i})∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from each worker i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ],

  2. 2.

    update the model via xk+1=xk−γ⁢1n⁢∑i=1n∇f⁢(xk;ξik)superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘𝛾1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑖x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{i})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_γ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

where [n]:={1,…,n}assigndelimited-[]𝑛1…𝑛[n]:=\{1,\ldots,n\}[ italic_n ] := { 1 , … , italic_n }, γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0italic_γ > 0 is a stepsize, ξiksubscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\xi^{k}_{i}italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are i.i.d. samples from 𝒟,𝒟\mathcal{D},caligraphic_D , and the gradients ∇f⁢(xk;ξik)∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{i})∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are calculated in parallel.

In real systems, each worker’s computational power may differ from the others, leading to varying completion times of gradient computation. A notable drawback of Minibatch SGD is its failure to account for these differences in compute times across workers. The duration of each step is determined by the slowest worker’s computation time. As a result, all other workers remain idle after completing their tasks, waiting for the slowest device to finish. Meanwhile, this idle time could potentially be used in a more efficient way to improve the overall time complexity. Clearly, a redesign of the algorithm is necessary.

1.2 Asynchronous SGD

As a result, a new generation of algorithms emerged, known as asynchronous stochastic gradient descent (ASGD) methods, designed to fully utilize all available computational resources (Recht et al., , 2011; Feyzmahdavian et al., , 2016; Nguyen et al., , 2018; Arjevani et al., , 2020; Cohen et al., , 2021; Mishchenko et al., , 2022; Koloskova et al., , 2022; Islamov et al., , 2023).

Here, the server performs a gradient-type update immediately after receiving a stochastic gradient from any worker, without waiting for the others. The updated model is then sent back to the worker, which immediately begins computing a new stochastic gradient based on the updated model. By the time the worker finishes computing this gradient, the model may have already been updated multiple times on the server due to gradients received from other workers. This creates a delay in the model update, denoted as δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k}italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The algorithm can be described as follows:

  1. 1.

    receive a stochastic gradient ∇f⁢(xk−δk;ξk−δk)∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘superscript𝜉𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘\nabla f(x^{k-\delta_{k}};\xi^{k-\delta_{k}})∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) from any worker,

  2. 2.

    update the model via xk+1=xk−γ⁢∇f⁢(xk−δk;ξk−δk)superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘𝛾∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘superscript𝜉𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\nabla f(x^{k-\delta_{k}};\xi^{k-\delta_{k}})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_γ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ),

  3. 3.

    send new xk+1superscript𝑥𝑘1x^{k+1}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the worker so the worker computes ∇f⁢(xk+1;ξk+1)∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝜉𝑘1\nabla f(x^{k+1};\xi^{k+1})∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Cohen et al., (2021); Mishchenko et al., (2022); Koloskova et al., (2022) showed that ASGD is provably faster in terms of time complexity then Minibatch SGD.

However, it turns out that this untamed and wild asynchrony can be detrimental. The drawback of ASGD lies in the assumption that all workers’ computations are beneficial. It suffers from the issue of updating the model with potentially significantly delayed gradients, which ultimately harms convergence and, consequently, the overall time complexity, as discussed in the work of Tyurin and Richtárik, (2024). To address this issue, there was a need to introduce a method that ignores outdated gradients while maintaining the philosophy of maximizing the utilization of available computational resources.

1.3 Rennala SGD

Such a method was proposed in a recent breakthrough by Tyurin and Richtárik, (2024). Their method which can be viewed as a modification of the Minibatch SGD method. At each iteration the server collects a batch of gradients, but it allows workers to send as many gradients as they can on the same point xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, using this batch, Rennala SGD proceeds with a gradient-type update using this batch as in Minibatch SGD:

  1. 1.

    wait until the server receives B𝐵Bitalic_B stochastic gradients at point xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  2. 2.

    update the model via xk+1=xk−γ⁢1B⁢∑j=1B∇f⁢(xk;ξjk)superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘𝛾1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐵∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑗x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\frac{1}{B}\sum_{j=1}^{B}\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{j})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_γ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

more details on Rennala SGD are in Appendix D. In this case, the faster the worker, the more gradients it sends. For the struggling workers, it may happen that they are completely ignored.

Their approach considers a setting where each worker i𝑖iitalic_i requires a fixed τi>0subscript𝜏𝑖0\tau_{i}>0italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 seconds to compute a stochastic gradient. For the first time lower bounds on time complexity were obtained for first order ASGD methods in the above mentioned fixed compute time regime for nonconvex functions with Lipschitz gradients. They showed that Rennala SGD is mini-max optimal in this setup in terms of time complexity.

While it may seem that the story is over, we want to question the fixed time assumption, arguing that a random time model is more realistic. The claim of optimality does not hold because of this randomness, suggesting that the algorithms need to be reevaluated and redesigned. We believe that a redesign is necessary to better fit this more realistic approach.

2 Problem Setup and Contributions

The deterministic compute time setup considered by Tyurin and Richtárik, (2024), where Rennala SGD is optimal, fails to capture the complexities of real-world distributed learning environments. In practice, compute times are often uncertain due to various factors such as failing hardware, preemption by other jobs, delays in GPU computation, and inconsistencies in network communications (Chen et al., , 2016; Dutta et al., , 2018). This uncertainty is even more pronounced in federated learning scenarios, where client unreliability can lead to unpredictable computation times or even incomplete tasks (Kairouz et al., , 2021).

2.1 Random compute times

To address these real-world challenges, we propose a more practical setup that incorporates randomness into compute times. Specifically, we consider a scenario where the stochastic gradient computation time of worker i𝑖iitalic_i is given by:

τi+ηi,subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖\tau_{i}+\eta_{i},italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2)

where τi>0subscript𝜏𝑖0\tau_{i}>0italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 is a constant representing the minimum time for client i𝑖iitalic_i to complete the gradient computation, and ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a non-negative random variable drawn from some distribution 𝒥isubscript𝒥𝑖\mathcal{J}_{i}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, modeling the aforementioned uncertainties.

In this more realistic setting, existing methods like Rennala SGD and ASGD can perform poorly or even fail to converge. We can illustrate this with a simple example:

Consider a scenario where each time we request a device to compute a stochastic gradient, one of two outcomes occurs. Either the device completes the computation exactly after the minimum time τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ without any delays, or something goes wrong and the computation is never completed. This situation can be modeled using a random time η𝜂\etaitalic_η as follows:

η={0,with probability ⁢1−q,∞,with probability ⁢q,𝜂cases0with probability 1𝑞with probability 𝑞\eta=\begin{cases}0,&\text{with probability }1-q,\\ \infty,&\text{with probability }q,\end{cases}italic_η = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL with probability 1 - italic_q , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∞ , end_CELL start_CELL with probability italic_q , end_CELL end_ROW (3)

where 0<q<10𝑞10<q<10 < italic_q < 1. In this scenario, any method that waits for a certain number of batches on each iteration to perform a step runs the risk of never receiving the required batch and getting stuck. This includes methods like Rennala SGD or ASGD. Specifically, if the algorithm waits for a single stochastic gradient on each iteration, there is a probability qnsuperscript𝑞𝑛q^{n}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that it will never receive it and consequently never proceed.

2.2 Summary of contributions

To address these limitations, we propose a new method that, unlike Rennala SGD or ASGD, does not wait for a fixed number of gradients (such as one in ASGD). Instead, it allocates a specific time for computing each stochastic gradient. If a client fails to complete its computation within the designated time, the partial computation is discarded, and a new computation is initiated. Our main contributions are as follows.

  • •

    In Section 4, we propose a new time efficient asynchronous parallel stochastic gradient descent method, MindFlayer SGD (Footnote 7), for the heterogeneous and random worker compute times regime (Equation 2). To the best of our knowledge, MindFlayer SGD is the first algorithm designed to work in this regime. We show that our method is a generalization of Rennala SGD, meaning that it is optimal in the deterministic compute times setup.

  • •

    In Section 5, we show that the theoretical time complexity of MindFlayer SGD can be arbitrarily faster than that of Rennala SGD or ASGD, depending on the distributions of computation times. Specifically, we demonstrate that if the distributions of computation times 𝒥isubscript𝒥𝑖\mathcal{J}_{i}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positively skewed, our method is faster, with the performance gap increasing as the skewness coefficient grows. As shown in Footnote 3, where 𝒥i=Lognormal⁢(0,s)subscript𝒥𝑖Lognormal0𝑠\mathcal{J}_{i}=\text{Lognormal}(0,s)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Lognormal ( 0 , italic_s ). As s𝑠sitalic_s gets bigger, the distribution’s skewness coefficient gets bigger and the performance of Rennala SGD or ASGD gets worse. Meanwhile, our method MindFlayer SGD is robust to the change of the variance.

  • •

    In Section 6, we experimentally validate this performance. We provide practical guidelines for using MindFlayer SGD, and demonstrate its superiority over Rennala SGD and ASGD. We conduct evaluations using various functions and distributions. For distributions, we consider Lognormal, Log-Cauchy, and the Infinite-Bernoulli (defined by Equation 3) distributions. Regarding the functions, we consider a quadratic loss and a neural network on the MNIST (LeCun et al., , 1998) dataset. This diverse testing setup enables us to showcase MindFlayer SGD’s robustness and effectiveness across various challenging scenarios.

  • •

    In Appendix C, we expand our theory to develop Vecna SGD, designed for the heterogeneous case, where workers have datasets that are coming from different distributions.

3 Motivation and Single Device Case

To illustrate the motivation behind the design of our new method, let us consider a single device setup. Recall the scenario introduced in Equation 3 where we have single device and it either returns a gradient after τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ time or gets stuck with probability q𝑞qitalic_q. A straightforward and optimal workaround to this issue is to wait exactly τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ seconds. If we do not receive a gradient within this time frame, it indicates that we will never receive it, so there is no point in waiting longer. In this case, we discard the current computation, which would take forever anyway, and request the device to compute the gradient again. The probability of getting stuck again is lower, so eventually, we will receive a gradient and move forward.

More generally, consider the following two strategies for each step:

  • •

    Strategy 1: Rennala SGD. We wait for the first B𝐵Bitalic_B stochastic gradients. Thus, the time for one step for this strategy is the random variable:

    TB=∑j=1B(τ+ηj).subscript𝑇𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐵𝜏superscript𝜂𝑗T_{B}=\sum_{j=1}^{B}(\tau+\eta^{j}).italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ + italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .
  • •

    Strategy 2: MindFlayer SGD. We repeat the following random trial B𝐵Bitalic_B times: allocate time t𝑡titalic_t for computing a stochastic gradient. If we do not receive a stochastic gradient within that time, discard the current computation and start over. Then the time for the j𝑗jitalic_j-th trial is given by:

    Tj⁢(t)={τ+ηj,if⁢ηj≤t,τ+t,if⁢ηj>t.superscript𝑇𝑗𝑡cases𝜏superscript𝜂𝑗ifsuperscript𝜂𝑗𝑡𝜏𝑡ifsuperscript𝜂𝑗𝑡T^{j}(t)=\begin{cases}\tau+\eta^{j},&\text{if}\enspace\eta^{j}\leq t,\\ \tau+t,&\text{if}\enspace\eta^{j}>t.\end{cases}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ + italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_t , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_τ + italic_t , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_t . end_CELL end_ROW

    Thus, the time for one step for this strategy is the random variable:

    T~B⁢(t)=∑j=1BTj⁢(t).subscript~𝑇𝐵𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐵superscript𝑇𝑗𝑡\tilde{T}_{B}(t)=\sum_{j=1}^{B}T^{j}(t).over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) .

In the second case, rather than waiting for B𝐵Bitalic_B gradients, we attempt to compute B𝐵Bitalic_B gradients. Essentially, we limit the time spent on computing a stochastic gradient. In expectation, Strategy 2 will collect B⁢p𝐵𝑝Bpitalic_B italic_p gradients per iteration, where p=P⁢(η≤t)𝑝𝑃𝜂𝑡p=P(\eta\leq t)italic_p = italic_P ( italic_η ≤ italic_t ) is the probability of collecting a gradient within a trial. Setting t=∞𝑡t=\inftyitalic_t = ∞ removes this restriction, resulting in the same strategy as the first one, Rennala SGD.

For MindFlayer SGD, each iteration, on average, receives only B⁢p𝐵𝑝Bpitalic_B italic_p gradients, making it effectively a scaled-down version of Rennala SGD. Consequently, MindFlayer SGD is expected to require 1/p1𝑝1/p1 / italic_p times more iterations than Rennala SGD to achieve the same level of convergence. We have the following proposition.

Proposition 3.1 (Proof in Appendix F).

Let K𝐾Kitalic_K be the number of iterations required by Rennala SGD to find an ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε-stationary point. Then, for sufficiently small ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε, MindFlayer SGD needs K/p𝐾𝑝K/pitalic_K / italic_p iterations to find an ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε-stationary point.

Thus, the time complexities in this setting are given by:

T𝖱𝖾𝗇𝗇𝖺𝗅𝖺𝖲𝖦𝖣=K⁢𝔼⁢[TB]=K⁢B⁢(τ+𝔼⁢[η]),subscript𝑇𝖱𝖾𝗇𝗇𝖺𝗅𝖺𝖲𝖦𝖣𝐾𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇𝐵𝐾𝐵𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝜂\displaystyle T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[% named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}RennalaSGD}}=K\mathbb{E}\left[T_{B}% \right]=KB(\tau+\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]),italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_RennalaSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_K blackboard_E [ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_K italic_B ( italic_τ + blackboard_E [ italic_η ] ) ,
T𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣⁢(t)=Kp⁢𝔼⁢[T~B⁢(t)]=Kp⁢B⁢(τ+(1−p)⁢t+p⁢𝔼⁢[τ|τ≤t])≤Kp⁢B⁢(τ+t).subscript𝑇𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣𝑡𝐾𝑝𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝑇𝐵𝑡𝐾𝑝𝐵𝜏1𝑝𝑡𝑝𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝜏𝜏𝑡𝐾𝑝𝐵𝜏𝑡\displaystyle T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[% named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}(t)=\frac{K}{p}% \mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{T}_{B}(t)\right]=\frac{K}{p}B(\tau+(1-p)t+p\mathbb{E}% \left[\tau|\tau\leq t\right])\leq\frac{K}{p}B(\tau+t).italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_p end_ARG blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ] = divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_p end_ARG italic_B ( italic_τ + ( 1 - italic_p ) italic_t + italic_p blackboard_E [ italic_τ | italic_τ ≤ italic_t ] ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_p end_ARG italic_B ( italic_τ + italic_t ) .

This leads us to the following observation.

Remark 3.2.

For the case where n=1𝑛1n=1italic_n = 1, MindFlayer SGD is faster than Rennala SGD if there exists a time threshold t>0𝑡0t>0italic_t > 0 such that the following inequality holds:

τ+tP⁢(η≤t)<τ+𝔼⁢[η].𝜏𝑡𝑃𝜂𝑡𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝜂\frac{\tau+t}{P(\eta\leq t)}<\tau+\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right].divide start_ARG italic_τ + italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_η ≤ italic_t ) end_ARG < italic_τ + blackboard_E [ italic_η ] .

It is important to note that this can hold for a wide range of values of t𝑡titalic_t, including any finite value. The latter is particularly relevant in cases where 𝔼⁢[η]=∞𝔼delimited-[]𝜂\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]=\inftyblackboard_E [ italic_η ] = ∞. An example of such a scenario is illustrated in Equation 3. There are many other distributions for which the expectation is not finite, such as the Log-Cauchy distribution, Lévy distribution, Log-t distribution, Landau distribution, and so forth.

A less restrictive example of distributions are positively skewed distributions. Let s=𝔼⁢[η]−Med⁢[η]𝑠𝔼delimited-[]𝜂Meddelimited-[]𝜂s=\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]-\mathrm{Med}[\eta]italic_s = blackboard_E [ italic_η ] - roman_Med [ italic_η ] be the skewness coefficient of the distribution 𝒥𝒥\mathcal{J}caligraphic_J. If s>0𝑠0s>0italic_s > 0 we say that the distribution is positively skewed. Then we have the following proposition.

Proposition 3.3.

[Proof in Appendix F] For the n=1𝑛1n=1italic_n = 1 case, if s>τ+Med⁢[η]𝑠𝜏Meddelimited-[]𝜂s>\tau+\mathrm{Med}[\eta]italic_s > italic_τ + roman_Med [ italic_η ] then MindFlayer SGD is faster than Rennala SGD. Moreover, if s=(τ+Med⁢[η])⁢(2⁢α−1)𝑠𝜏Meddelimited-[]𝜂2𝛼1s=\left(\tau+\mathrm{Med}[\eta]\right)\left(2\alpha-1\right)italic_s = ( italic_τ + roman_Med [ italic_η ] ) ( 2 italic_α - 1 ) then

T𝖱𝖾𝗇𝗇𝖺𝗅𝖺𝖲𝖦𝖣T𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣⁢(Med⁢[η])≥α.subscript𝑇𝖱𝖾𝗇𝗇𝖺𝗅𝖺𝖲𝖦𝖣subscript𝑇𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣Meddelimited-[]𝜂𝛼\frac{T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}RennalaSGD}}}{T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[% rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}% MindFlayerSGD}}\left(\mathrm{Med}[\eta]\right)}\geq\alpha.divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_RennalaSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Med [ italic_η ] ) end_ARG ≥ italic_α .

Therefore, Rennala SGD can be arbitrarily bad. As an example consider the Lognormal(μ,σ2)𝜇superscript𝜎2(\mu,\sigma^{2})( italic_μ , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) distribution. For this distribution, we have:

s=𝔼⁢[η]−Med⁢[η]=exp⁡(μ+σ22)−exp⁡(μ).𝑠𝔼delimited-[]𝜂Meddelimited-[]𝜂𝜇superscript𝜎22𝜇s=\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]-\mathrm{Med}[\eta]=\exp\left(\mu+\frac{\sigma^{2% }}{2}\right)-\exp(\mu).italic_s = blackboard_E [ italic_η ] - roman_Med [ italic_η ] = roman_exp ( italic_μ + divide start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) - roman_exp ( italic_μ ) .

Thus, as we increase σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, the difference becomes arbitrarily large.

To verify this, we also conducted a small experiment, see Footnote 5. The right plot showcases how the ratio of time complexity between Rennala SGD and MindFlayer SGD can get arbitrarily large for the optimal clipping time t∗:=arg⁡mint⁡T𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣⁢(t)assignsuperscript𝑡subscript𝑡subscript𝑇𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣𝑡t^{*}:=\arg\min_{t}T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}% \definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) and even the median of the distribution tmedian=Med⁢[η]subscript𝑡medianMeddelimited-[]𝜂t_{\text{median}}=\mathrm{Med}[\eta]italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT median end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Med [ italic_η ]. The left and middle plots showcase the potential improvement, and even loss from choosing different clipping times t𝑡titalic_t.

4 MindFlayer SGD

Here, we propose our MindFlayer SGD algorithm for multiple device case (n>1𝑛1n>1italic_n > 1). For the heterogeneous case, please refer to Appendix C.

The MindFlayer SGD algorithm begins with an initialization at a starting point x0superscript𝑥0x^{0}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with a specified stepsize γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0italic_γ > 0, time allowances ti>0subscript𝑡𝑖0t_{i}>0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, and trial counts Bi≥0subscript𝐵𝑖0B_{i}\geq 0italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 for each client. In each iteration k𝑘kitalic_k, ranging from k=1𝑘1k=1italic_k = 1 to K𝐾Kitalic_K, the server distributes the current point xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to all clients. Each client i𝑖iitalic_i then executes a subroutine (Algorithm 2) to attempt to compute Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stochastic gradients from samples ξijsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗\xi_{i}^{j}italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT drawn from a distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. During each attempt, client i𝑖iitalic_i starts computing a stochastic gradient; if the computation exceeds the allotted time tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, they discard the current gradient and begin another computation. Consequently, the actual number of stochastic gradients received from each client i𝑖iitalic_i becomes a random variable, ranging from 00 to Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The expected number of gradients from client i𝑖iitalic_i is given by pi⁢Bisubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖p_{i}B_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, leading to an overall expected total of stochastic gradients B=∑i=1npi⁢Bi𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}B_{i}italic_B = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The server aggregates these received stochastic gradients and normalizes the collective gradient by the expected batch size B𝐵Bitalic_B. Finally, the point is updated to xk+1=xk−γ⁢gksuperscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘𝛾superscript𝑔𝑘x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma g^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_γ italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT following each aggregation round.

In the special case where the computation time is deterministic, i.e., ηi=0subscript𝜂𝑖0\eta_{i}=0italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for every worker i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], we have pi=1subscript𝑝𝑖1p_{i}=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all i𝑖iitalic_i. While Rennala SGD does not explicitly specify the number of gradient computations Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each client, in the deterministic setting, each client will send a fixed number of gradients per communication round. Consequently, for any t>0𝑡0t>0italic_t > 0, MindFlayer SGD Footnote 7, by choosing Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT appropriately, reduces to Rennala SGD Algorithm 5.

However, the situation changes when ηi>0subscript𝜂𝑖0\eta_{i}>0italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 is not a constant random variable. If we set ti=∞subscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}=\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∞ for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], MindFlayer SGD Footnote 7 does not reduce to Rennala SGD Algorithm 5. This is because, in the case of Rennala SGD, the randomness in each iteration causes the number of stochastic gradients computed by each client to vary across different communication rounds. Nevertheless, this scenario is not our primary focus, as we will demonstrate that allowing each worker to complete its gradient computation by setting ti=∞subscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}=\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∞ is inefficient when dealing with positively skewed distributions.

To continue with the analysis of MindFlayer SGD, we first present the assumptions under which this method is studied.

4.1 Assumptions

We consider standard assumptions used in the nonconvex optimization.

Assumption 4.1.

Function f𝑓fitalic_f is differentiable, and its gradient is L𝐿Litalic_L–Lipschitz continuous, i.e., ‖∇f⁢(x)−∇f⁢(y)‖≤L⁢‖x−y‖norm∇𝑓𝑥∇𝑓𝑦𝐿norm𝑥𝑦\left\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\right\|\leq L\left\|x-y\right\|∥ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ) - ∇ italic_f ( italic_y ) ∥ ≤ italic_L ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥, for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Assumption 4.2.

There exist finf∈ℝsuperscript𝑓infimumℝf^{\inf}\in\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R such that f⁢(x)≥finf𝑓𝑥superscript𝑓infimumf(x)\geq f^{\inf}italic_f ( italic_x ) ≥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Assumption 4.3.

For all x∈ℝd,𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d},italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , stochastic gradients ∇f⁢(x;ξ)∇𝑓𝑥𝜉\nabla f(x;\xi)∇ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_ξ ) are unbiased and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-variance-bounded, i.e., 𝔼ξ⁢[∇f⁢(x;ξ)]=∇f⁢(x)subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]∇𝑓𝑥𝜉∇𝑓𝑥{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}\left[\nabla f(x;\xi)\right]=\nabla f(x)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_ξ ) ] = ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ) and 𝔼ξ⁢[‖∇f⁢(x;ξ)−∇f⁢(x)‖2]≤σ2subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥𝜉∇𝑓𝑥2superscript𝜎2{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}\left[\left\|\nabla f(x;\xi)-\nabla f(x)\right\|^{2}\right]% \leq\sigma^{2}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∥ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_ξ ) - ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where σ2≥0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}\geq 0italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0.

4.2 Convergence theory

The following theorem gives iterations guarantees for the convergence of Rennala SGD.

Even though MindFlayer SGD is similar to Rennala SGD the convergence analysis require additional considerations, since the batch size is a random variable here as apposed to the case of Rennala SGD.

Theorem 4.4.

Assume that Assumptions 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3 hold. Let B=∑i=1npi⁢Bi𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}B_{i}italic_B = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and γ=12⁢L⁢min⁡{1,ε⁢Bσ2}𝛾12𝐿1𝜀𝐵superscript𝜎2\gamma=\frac{1}{2L}\min\left\{1,\frac{\varepsilon B}{\sigma^{2}}\right\}italic_γ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG roman_min { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_ε italic_B end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG } in Footnote 7. Then, after

K≥max⁡{1,σ2ε⁢B}⁢8⁢L⁢(f⁢(x0)−finf)ε𝐾1superscript𝜎2𝜀𝐵8𝐿𝑓superscript𝑥0superscript𝑓infimum𝜀K\geq\max\left\{1,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon B}\right\}\frac{8L\left(f(x^{0% })-f^{\inf}\right)}{\varepsilon}italic_K ≥ roman_max { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε italic_B end_ARG } divide start_ARG 8 italic_L ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG

iterations, the method guarantees that 1K⁢∑k=0K−1𝔼⁢[‖∇f⁢(xk)‖2]≤ε1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘2𝜀\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\|\nabla f(x^{k})\right\|^{2% }\right]\leq\varepsilondivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ∥ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_ε.

Sketch of Proof.

(Complete proof in Section G.1) We consider Footnote 7 as a conventional SGD using the following gradient estimator:

g⁢(x)=1B⁢∑i=1n∑j=1BiI⁢(ηij≤ti)⁢∇f⁢(x;ξij),𝑔𝑥1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐵𝑖𝐼superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖𝑗subscript𝑡𝑖∇𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗g(x)=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{B_{i}}I(\eta_{i}^{j}\leq t_{i})% \nabla f(x;\xi_{i}^{j}),italic_g ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I ( italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where I⁢(⋅)𝐼⋅I(\cdot)italic_I ( ⋅ ) denotes the indicator function. Prior to applying the classical SGD theorem (Theorem E.2), it is essential to verify that this estimator meets the theorem’s conditions, namely unbiasedness and a specific bound on the second moment of g⁢(x)𝑔𝑥g(x)italic_g ( italic_x ). We demonstrate that the estimator is unbiased, and that

𝔼⁢[‖g⁢(x)2‖]≤2⁢‖∇f⁢(x)‖2+1B⁢σ2.𝔼delimited-[]norm𝑔superscript𝑥22superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥21𝐵superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g(x)^{2}\right\|\right]\leq 2\left\|\nabla f(x)\right\|% ^{2}+\frac{1}{B}\sigma^{2}.blackboard_E [ ∥ italic_g ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ] ≤ 2 ∥ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

With these conditions satisfied, we can proceed to apply Theorem E.2. ∎

Note that in the deterministic case where ηi=0subscript𝜂𝑖0\eta_{i}=0italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], we have pi=P⁢(ηi≤ti)=1subscript𝑝𝑖𝑃subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖1p_{i}=P(\eta_{i}\leq t_{i})=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P ( italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]. Therefore, we derive

K≥max⁡{1,σ2ε⁢B}⁢8⁢L⁢(f⁢(x0)−finf)ε,𝐾1superscript𝜎2𝜀𝐵8𝐿𝑓superscript𝑥0superscript𝑓infimum𝜀K\geq\max\left\{1,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon B}\right\}\frac{8L\left(f(x^{0% })-f^{\inf}\right)}{\varepsilon},italic_K ≥ roman_max { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε italic_B end_ARG } divide start_ARG 8 italic_L ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ,

with B=∑i=1nBi𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐵𝑖B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}B_{i}italic_B = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, yielding the same result as Rennala SGD, up to a constant factor.

We also achieve the same rate as ti→∞→subscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}\to\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → ∞ for all i𝑖iitalic_i, since in that scenario pi→1→subscript𝑝𝑖1p_{i}\to 1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 1. This is expected because we will observe a consistent number of stochastic gradients each time, though the timing may vary, as mentioned earlier.

However, if ti=0subscript𝑡𝑖0t_{i}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], then K=∞𝐾K=\inftyitalic_K = ∞. This result is anticipated since, in this case, the success probability is zero for all clients, and thus the server never receives stochastic gradients.

4.3 Time Complexity

The following theorem gives time complexity for MindFlayer SGD.

Theorem 4.5 (Proof in Section G.2).

Assume that Assumptions 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3 hold. Let B=∑i=1npi⁢Bi𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}B_{i}italic_B = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and γ=12⁢L⁢min⁡{1,ε⁢Bσ2}𝛾12𝐿1𝜀𝐵superscript𝜎2\gamma=\frac{1}{2L}\min\left\{1,\frac{\varepsilon B}{\sigma^{2}}\right\}italic_γ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG roman_min { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_ε italic_B end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG } in Method 7. Let t=(t1,…,tn)𝑡subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑛t=\left(t_{1},\ldots,t_{n}\right)italic_t = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), t1,…,tn≥0subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑛0t_{1},\ldots,t_{n}\geq 0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0. Without loss of generality assume that 0<τ1+t1≤⋯≤τn+tn0subscript𝜏1subscript𝑡1⋯subscript𝜏𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛0<\tau_{1}+t_{1}\leq\cdots\leq\tau_{n}+t_{n}0 < italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ ⋯ ≤ italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let

t⁢(m)=(∑j=1mpjτj+tj)−1⁢(S+∑j=1mpj),𝑡𝑚superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑗t(m)=\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{p_{j}}{\tau_{j}+t_{j}}\right)^{-1}\left(S+\sum_% {j=1}^{m}p_{j}\right),italic_t ( italic_m ) = ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where S=max⁡{1,σ2ε}𝑆1superscript𝜎2𝜀S=\max\left\{1,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon}\right\}italic_S = roman_max { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG }. Let m∗=arg⁡minm∈[n]⁡t⁢(m)superscript𝑚subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑛𝑡𝑚m^{*}=\arg\min_{m\in[n]}t(m)italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ( italic_m ), if there are several minimizers we take the smallest one. Put

Bi=⌈bi⌉,bi={t⁢(m∗)τi+ti−1,if⁢i≤m∗,0,if⁢i>m∗.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖cases𝑡superscript𝑚subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖1if𝑖superscript𝑚0if𝑖superscript𝑚B_{i}=\lceil b_{i}\rceil,\quad b_{i}=\begin{cases}\frac{t(m^{*})}{\tau_{i}+t_{% i}}-1,&\text{if}\enspace i\leq m^{*},\\ 0,&\text{if}\enspace i>m^{*}.\end{cases}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⌈ italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⌉ , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_t ( italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i ≤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i > italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW

Then, MindFlayer SGD guarantees to find an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-stationary point after

T𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣⁢(t)≥8×minm∈[n]⁡{(1m⁢∑j=1mpjτj+tj)−1⁢(Sm+1m⁢∑j=1mpj)⁢Δ⁢Lε}subscript𝑇𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣𝑡8subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑛superscript1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑆𝑚1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑗Δ𝐿𝜀T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)\geq 8\times\min_{m\in[% n]}\left\{\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{p_{j}}{\tau_{j}+t_{j}}\right)^{% -1}\left(\frac{S}{m}+\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}p_{j}\right)\frac{\Delta L}{% \varepsilon}\right\}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ≥ 8 × roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG roman_Δ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG }

seconds, where Δ=f⁢(x0)−finfΔ𝑓subscript𝑥0superscript𝑓infimum\Delta=f(x_{0})-f^{\inf}roman_Δ = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The theorem indicates that the optimal strategy is to disregard devices with a high value of τi+ti/pisubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\nicefrac{{\tau_{i}+t_{i}}}{{p_{i}}}/ start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Therefore, we should prioritize devices that not only have a high probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of completing the gradient within the allotted time tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but also have a relatively small sum of τi+tisubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖\tau_{i}+t_{i}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This approach is logical as it avoids including devices with substantial computation times and low probabilities of completing their tasks within the specified duration.

In the deterministic case where ηi=0subscript𝜂𝑖0\eta_{i}=0italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], we have pi=1subscript𝑝𝑖1p_{i}=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all i𝑖iitalic_i. Consequently, the time complexity of MindFlayer SGD at time t𝑡titalic_t is given by

T𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣⁢(t)≥8×minm∈[n]⁡{(1m⁢∑j=1m1τj+tj)−1⁢(Sm+1)⁢Δ⁢Lε}.subscript𝑇𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣𝑡8subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑛superscript1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚1subscript𝜏𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗1𝑆𝑚1Δ𝐿𝜀T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)\geq 8\times\min_{m\in[% n]}\left\{\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\tau_{j}+t_{j}}\right)^{-1}% \left(\frac{S}{m}+1\right)\frac{\Delta L}{\varepsilon}\right\}.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ≥ 8 × roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + 1 ) divide start_ARG roman_Δ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG } .

Thus, the optimal choice of tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is ti=0subscript𝑡𝑖0t_{i}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]. Therefore, the final time complexity becomes

T𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣⁢(t)≥8×minm∈[n]⁡{(1m⁢∑j=1m1τj)−1⁢(1m+1)⁢Δ⁢Lε}.subscript𝑇𝖬𝗂𝗇𝖽𝖥𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖦𝖣𝑡8subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑛superscript1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚1subscript𝜏𝑗11𝑚1Δ𝐿𝜀T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)\geq 8\times\min_{m\in[% n]}\left\{\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\tau_{j}}\right)^{-1}\left(% \frac{1}{m}+1\right)\frac{\Delta L}{\varepsilon}\right\}.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ≥ 8 × roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + 1 ) divide start_ARG roman_Δ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG } .

This formulation recovers the time complexity for Rennala SGD.

We still have the freedom to choose the tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT allocation times. The optimal strategy would be to select them in a manner that minimizes the time complexity. As observed in Footnote 5, setting ti=Med⁢[ηi]subscript𝑡𝑖Meddelimited-[]subscript𝜂𝑖t_{i}=\mathrm{Med}\left[\eta_{i}\right]italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Med [ italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] proves to be a viable choice. This is further confirmed by our experiments in Section 6.

5 Comparing to Rennala SGD

Comparing the theoretical performance of Rennala SGD and MindFlayer SGD is particularly challenging due to the inherent randomness in the time complexity of Rennala SGD and the dependence of MindFlayer SGD on optimizing time variables tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, a comparison using the expected time complexity may fail to capture the nuances of each algorithm’s performance across different distributions. Thus, we turn to an empirical comparison to provide insights into their practical behavior. In particular, we aim to demonstrate how MindFlayer SGD can achieve arbitrarily better performance in scenarios where the distributions are positively skewed (see Figure 3).

To begin, we derive the time complexity of Rennala SGD in the context of random times. Let ℬ:={(B1,B2,…,Bn):Bi∈ℕ0;∑i=1nBi=B}assignℬconditional-setsubscript𝐵1subscript𝐵2…subscript𝐵𝑛formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑖subscriptℕ0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐵𝑖𝐵\mathcal{B}:=\left\{(B_{1},B_{2},\ldots,B_{n}):B_{i}\in\mathbb{N}_{0};\sum_{i=% 1}^{n}B_{i}=B\right\}caligraphic_B := { ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_B } be the set of all possible batch sizes for each device, the time TBsubscript𝑇𝐵T_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT required for one step with batch size B𝐵Bitalic_B of Rennala SGD is given by:

TBsubscript𝑇𝐵\displaystyle T_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =minℬ⁡{maxi∈[1,n]⁡{Bi⁢τi+∑j=1Biηij}}≥T1absentsubscriptℬsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐵𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖𝑗subscript𝑇1\displaystyle=\min_{\mathcal{B}}\left\{\max_{i\in[1,n]}\left\{B_{i}\tau_{i}+% \sum_{j=1}^{B_{i}}\eta_{i}^{j}\right\}\right\}\geq T_{1}= roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ 1 , italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } } ≥ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=mini∈[n]⁡{τi+ηi1}≥mini∈[n]⁡{τi}+mini∈[n]⁡{ηi1}.absentsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖1\displaystyle=\min_{i\in[n]}\left\{\tau_{i}+\eta_{i}^{1}\right\}\geq\min_{i\in% [n]}\left\{\tau_{i}\right\}+\min_{i\in[n]}\left\{\eta_{i}^{1}\right\}.= roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ≥ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } + roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } .

Thus, the expected time to collect a batch B𝐵Bitalic_B is

𝔼⁢[TB]≥τmin+𝔼⁢[mini∈[n]⁡ηi],𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇𝐵subscript𝜏𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜂𝑖\mathbb{E}\left[T_{B}\right]\geq\tau_{\min}+\mathbb{E}\left[\min_{i\in[n]}\eta% _{i}\right],blackboard_E [ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ≥ italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

Note that if the distribution of mini∈[n]⁡ηisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜂𝑖\min_{i\in[n]}\eta_{i}roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is heavy-tailed, then the expected time complexity becomes infinite, thus favoring MindFlayer SGD over Rennala SGD. A simple illustration of this occurs when extending the Equation 3 case, where η𝜂\etaitalic_η is either zero or infinite, to scenarios involving multiple devices. In such cases, the expectation of the minimum time across devices, mini∈[n]⁡ηisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜂𝑖\min_{i\in[n]}\eta_{i}roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, also results in an infinite expected time complexity.

While a detailed theoretical comparison is intractable, we conduct an empirical comparison to highlight practical differences between the two algorithms. To capture the randomness of Rennala SGD’s rate, we generate a histogram: we create a histogram for TBsubscript𝑇𝐵T_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then convolve it K𝐾Kitalic_K times with itself. Where K𝐾Kitalic_K is the number of iterations required for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-convergence.

The time complexity of Rennala SGD is a random variable that is the sum of K𝐾Kitalic_K copies of TBsubscript𝑇𝐵T_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where is K𝐾Kitalic_K is the number of iterations to get ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-convergence.

For MindFlayer SGD, we evaluate two strategies for selecting tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: (1) using the median of the distributions 𝒥isubscript𝒥𝑖\mathcal{J}_{i}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and (2) solving the following optimization problem:

Fix m∈[n]𝑚delimited-[]𝑛m\in[n]italic_m ∈ [ italic_n ], minimize t⁢(m)𝑡𝑚t(m)italic_t ( italic_m ) over t=(t1,…,tn)𝑡subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑛t=(t_{1},…,t_{n})italic_t = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), (remember pj=Fj⁢(tj)subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝐹𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗p_{j}=F_{j}(t_{j})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )).

We optimize this using the L-BFGS-B algorithm, a well-suited method for solving smooth, convex, or mildly nonconvex problems due to its efficiency and robustness (Zhu et al., , 1997). For each m𝑚mitalic_m, we take the minimum over all possible configurations.

Our empirical results, illustrated in Figure 3, demonstrate that as the variance of the underlying distribution increases, MindFlayer SGD consistently outperforms Rennala SGD. The heavy-tailed nature of the distributions causes Rennala SGD to experience extreme slowdowns, while MindFlayer SGD maintains robust performance.

6 Experiments

In this section we explain the setup for comparing MindFlayer SGD, Rennala SGD, and ASGD, which we used throughout this paper. We compare the algorithms’ performance on a quadratic optimization (4) task with access to a stochastic gradient. The parallelism was simulated on a machine with 2 Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6226R CPUs @ 2.90GHz, with a total of 64 logical CPUs. For each setting of the algorithm, we run 10 different seeds for the random time and plot the average, minimum and maximum, see Footnote 3, Footnote 5, etc.

We use a similar setup to the one employed by Tyurin and Richtárik, (2024), but modify it so that we have a known expected variance. We make this choice, so we can compare theoretical parameters, as we did in Footnote 5.

Furthermore, we consider the homogeneous optimization problem (1), with the convex quadratic function

f⁢(x)=12⁢x⊤⁢A⁢x−b⊤⁢x,x∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝑓𝑥12superscript𝑥top𝐴𝑥superscript𝑏top𝑥𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑f(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}Ax-b^{\top}x,\qquad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.italic_f ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_x - italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x , italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

We take d=1000𝑑1000d=1000italic_d = 1000,

A=14⁢[2−10−1⋱⋱⋱⋱−10−12]∈ℝd×dandb=14⁢[−10⋮0]∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝐴14matrix21missing-subexpression01⋱⋱missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression⋱⋱10missing-subexpression12superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑and𝑏14matrix10⋮0superscriptℝ𝑑A=\frac{1}{4}\begin{bmatrix}2&-1&&0\\ -1&\ddots&\ddots&\\ &\ddots&\ddots&-1\\ 0&&-1&2\\ \end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}\quad\text{and}\quad b=\frac{1}{4}\begin% {bmatrix}-1\\ 0\\ \vdots\\ 0\\ \end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.italic_A = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL ⋱ end_CELL start_CELL ⋱ end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL ⋱ end_CELL start_CELL ⋱ end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d × italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and italic_b = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ⋮ end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (4)

Assume that all n𝑛nitalic_n workers has access to the following unbiased stochastic gradients:

[∇f⁢(x,ξ)]j:=∇jf⁢(x)+ξ,assignsubscriptdelimited-[]∇𝑓𝑥𝜉𝑗subscript∇𝑗𝑓𝑥𝜉\left[\nabla f(x,\xi)\right]_{j}:=\nabla_{j}f(x)+\xi,[ ∇ italic_f ( italic_x , italic_ξ ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) + italic_ξ ,

where ξ∼𝒩⁢(0,0.00032)similar-to𝜉𝒩0superscript0.00032\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,0.0003^{2})italic_ξ ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.0003 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), thus, we get that in 4.3 we have,

σ2=0.00032⋅d=0.00032⋅1000.superscript𝜎2⋅superscript0.00032𝑑⋅superscript0.000321000\sigma^{2}=0.0003^{2}\cdot d=0.0003^{2}\cdot 1000.italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.0003 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_d = 0.0003 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ 1000 .

Now setting the convergence threshold ϵ=10−4italic-ϵsuperscript104\epsilon=10^{-4}italic_ϵ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can infer all theoretical parameters. To find the optimal time corresponding to Rennala SGD we need to fix the times, we do that by either removing the randomness, or adding the expected randomness.

On the other hand, for MindFlayer SGD we use the results from Theorem 4.5 to set the theoretical number of trials for each client. In addition to the experimental results shown throughout the paper, we ran two more experiments. One with the Infinite-Bernoulli distribution on the same quadratic problem, and a second with the Log-Cauchy distribution with a small two-layer neural network on the MNIST (LeCun et al., , 1998) dataset, see Figures 4 and 5.

In Figures 4 and 5, we observe key insights regarding the performance of MindFlayer SGD, Rennala SGD, and ASGD under different stochastic gradient scenarios.

Figure 4 illustrates the behavior of the algorithms as we vary the probability of failure q𝑞qitalic_q in the InfBernoulli distribution. Notably, as q𝑞qitalic_q increases, both Rennala SGD and ASGD tend to stagnate, indicating their sensitivity to higher failure rates. In contrast, MindFlayer SGD maintains its optimization trajectory, demonstrating robust performance even in the presence of increased failure probability. This suggests that MindFlayer SGD is more resilient to stochastic disruptions, effectively continuing the optimization process without getting stuck.

Figure 5 presents the performance of the algorithms on a two-layer Neural Network trained on the MNIST dataset, varying the scale parameter s𝑠sitalic_s of the Log-Cauchy distribution. Here, we observe that MindFlayer SGD is less affected by larger variance of compute times, achieving convergence without significant delays. In contrast, Rennala SGD and ASGD experience notable delays with increasing variance, indicating that their convergence rates are adversely affected in such scenarios. This highlights the efficiency of MindFlayer SGD in handling high-variance, positively skewed computation times, making it a more reliable choice.

7 Conclusion and Future Work

In this paper, we address the problem of minimizing the expectation of nonconvex functions with Lipschitz gradients, with the use of parallel workers computing stochastic gradients. Our focus lies on the challenging scenario where worker compute times are heterogeneous and random, expanding on recent developments in ASGD methods like Rennala SGD. We observe that while Rennala SGD performs optimally in environments with deterministic compute times, its effectiveness diminishes under random compute conditions.

To better understand and improve stochastic optimization in these conditions, we introduce a novel asynchronous SGD method named MindFlayer SGD. This method adjusts to the randomness in computation times by not adhering to a fixed batch size but rather setting specific times for computing single stochastic gradients. If a client fails to deliver within this time frame, the computation is discarded, and the process restarts. This flexibility allows MindFlayer SGD to perform robustly across various conditions, notably outperforming both Rennala SGD and standard Asynchronous SGD (ASGD) in our theoretical and empirical analysis.

Our results demonstrate that MindFlayer SGD significantly reduces time complexity, particularly in environments characterized by positively skewed distribution of computation times. We empirically validate this in simulations with several distributions conditions where MindFlayer SGD consistently outperforms the other methods, particularly in high-variance scenarios. This showcases its superiority in adapting to the unpredictable duration of gradient computations typical in real-world applications such as federated learning environments.

In this study, our analysis was confined to computation times, with no consideration given to communication times. Future research will extend our investigation to include communication times. Moreover, we plan to explore the application of gradient estimators with varying variance bounds across different clients. We hypothesize that controlling these variance bounds could yield further benefits in the optimization process.

Ackowledgements

The research reported in this publication was supported by funding from King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST): i) KAUST Baseline Research Scheme, ii) Center of Excellence for Generative AI, under award number 5940, iii) SDAIA-KAUST Center of Excellence in Artificial Intelligence and Data Science.
